headline.main-hed: Afghan Presidential Candidate Boycotts Vote Count

alt-summary-body.p: The candidate who led Afghanistan's first round of presidential voting said he is boycotting the vote count for the final round because of alleged fraud, spurring a political crisis that threatens to destabilize the country as foreign troops leave.

summary-body.p: The candidate who led Afghanistan's first round of presidential voting said he is boycotting the vote count for the final round because of alleged fraud, spurring a political crisis that threatens to destabilize the country as foreign troops leave.

headline.main-hed: Afghan Candidate Boycotts Count of Votes
headline.deck: Abdullah, a Karzai Rival, Alleges Fraud in Presidential Runoff, Citing Outsize Turnout in Opponent's Areas of Support

media.media-caption: Abdullah Abdullah, right, leaves a Wednesday news conference in Kabul in which he urged a halt to the tallying of votes from Saturday's runoff.

article-body.p: KABUL—The candidate who led Afghanistan's first round of presidential voting said he is boycotting the vote count for the final round because of alleged fraud, spurring a political crisis that threatens to destabilize the country as foreign troops leave.

A clean election was supposed to be the landmark achievement of the 13-year international effort in Afghanistan, marking the first democratic transfer of power in the country's history. Foreign donors have tied a legitimate vote to the flow of billions of dollars in foreign aid that keep the Afghan economy and security forces afloat.

A disputed outcome, some Western diplomats and Afghan officials say, could cause violent unrest as foreign troops depart. Foreign monitors, Western diplomats and the United Nations have said the country's electoral bodies should take fraud allegations seriously, and they expect fraudulent ballots to be disqualified.

Abdullah Abdullah garnered 45% of the votes in the election's first round on April 5, against ex-Finance Minister Ashraf Ghani's 31.6%. His campaign officials say they believe that, because of the alleged fraud, Mr. Ghani is winning the runoff by around a million votes. The Independent Election Commission put the turnout at more than seven million, a figure disputed by Mr. Abdullah and some independent election observers, who say they believe the actual turnout was roughly five million.

"We suspend our engagement with the commission," Mr. Abdullah said, demanding the removal of the country's chief electoral officer and the creation of a neutral committee to adjudicate his fraud claims. "We are asking for the counting process to be stopped immediately."

highlight.link: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Five Militants

article-body.p: Yusuf Nuristani, chairman of the IEC , which organized the election and is counting the votes, said Saturday's turnout was up from 6.6 million in the first round. While turnout was largely the same or lower in much of the country, the IEC's initial tallies indicated a dramatic surge—in the areas of eastern Afghanistan that are Mr. Ghani's base.
In the eastern province of Khost, for example, initial IEC tallies showed that more than 400,000 voters cast ballots on Saturday, up from 113,000 in the first round.

According to the 2012-13 data compiled by Afghanistan's central statistics office, Khost's entire population is 549,000—and, given Afghanistan's demographic structure, at least one-third of them are children.
In the nearby province of Paktika, 390,000 voters cast their ballots on Saturday, up from 180,000. The province's population is 414,000.

Mr. Abdullah, a former foreign minister and civil-war-era mujahedeen leader, said on Wednesday that since such a turnout is "not in proportion to the population of that area, let alone the security situation" there, he believes that the election is being stolen.
Eastern Afghanistan is a hotbed of the Taliban insurgency, which launched hundreds of attacks on Saturday, trying to disrupt the vote.

"This is the worst-case scenario for the foreign community in Afghanistan," said Graeme Smith, a senior analyst with the International Crisis Group in Afghanistan. "Diplomats had been hoping that somebody would win clearly and decisively because there is important business to attend to."

Of paramount concern is signing a security agreement that would allow some 9,800 U.S. troops to remain after the current combat mission ends in December. President Hamid Karzai, who has ruled Afghanistan since the 2001 U.S.-led invasion and isn't allowed by law to contest this election, has refused to sign the agreement. Messrs. Abdullah and Ghani have pledged to quickly endorse the deal. Mr. Karzai's office has set the inauguration of the new president for Aug. 2—a deadline threatened by the conflict over the results. Military officials say they need the agreement in place by September at the latest.
At a Senate hearing on Wednesday, James Dobbins, the U.S. special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, urged the candidates and their supporters to remain patient.
"It will be some time before we know the outcome of the vote," he said. "Premature or undocumented allegations of fraud are as dangerous as fraud itself."
Mr. Nuristani has urged Mr. Abdullah since Saturday to bring all the evidence he has to the separate watchdog charged with adjudicating the election, the Independent Electoral Complaints Commission.

Noor Mohammad Noor, an IEC spokesman, added that vote counting would continue as planned despite Mr. Abdullah's pullout, and the preliminary results would be released on time. "The process is ongoing," Mr. Noor said.
The IEC plans to publish the preliminary results on July 2.
The country's electoral watchdog has several weeks to review the 568 complaints of election-day violations it received. Only after that will the commission release final results.
Mr. Ghani's campaign team explained the high turnout in eastern Afghanistan by its successful mobilization of voters and rejected allegations of widespread fraud.

Faizullah Zaki, a spokesman for Mr. Ghani, on Wednesday said the authority of the election bodies should be respected. "The result must be accepted by all candidates, whatever it is," he said. "This is the job of the IEC, and we should all patiently wait for them to make their announcement."
On Wednesday, Mr. Abdullah also accused Mr. Karzai of trying to engineer the result of the vote against him. "The president of Afghanistan wasn't neutral," he said.

Mr. Abdullah was the president's main opponent in the 2009 election, which was marred by widespread fraud. At the time, the electoral watchdog threw out as fraudulent more than a million ballots, most of them cast for Mr. Karzai.

Mr. Karzai's spokeswoman, Adela Raz, said the president respects both candidates and has been in contact with them. "We hope that these disagreements will be solved according to the law and what is best for the Afghan people and Afghanistan," she added.
Mr. Abdullah has demanded the removal of the IEC's chief electoral officer, Ziaulhaq Amarkhil, a request that so far has been ignored.

Mr. Abdullah on Wednesday floated the possibility of a forming a joint commission between his representatives and those of Mr. Ghani, under the supervision of the U.N., to adjudicate the dispute over the election's outcome.

"With the utmost concern, the U.N. Mission notes that appeals to circumvent or abandon the legal process and framework and appeal directly to supporters could incite violence," the U.N. mission in Afghanistan said Wednesday evening. The mission "strongly urges the candidates to take all steps necessary to control their supporters to prevent them from making any irresponsible statements and from taking steps that could lead to civil disorder and instability."
For the time being, Mr. Abdullah said his campaign team will pull its monitors from vote-counting centers and from the headquarters of Afghanistan's election commission in Kabul.

In preliminary assessments of Saturday's vote, domestic and foreign observers reported irregularities that included ballot stuffing and proxy voting across the country, but said these weren't systematic.
article-body.tagline: Nathan Hodge and Habib Khan Totakhil contributed to this article.
article-body.p: Write to Margherita Stancati at margherita.stancati@wsj.com
